The upÄsaka Zhi Qian, whose courtesy name was Gongming.
Also known as Yue.
He was a person from the great Yuezhi.
His grandfather Fadut led hundreds of people from the country to take refuge in the Han Dynasty during the reign of Emperor Ling of the Han Dynasty.
He was appointed as the General of the Central Lang of the Good.
At the age of seven, he rode a bamboo horse and played in his neighbor's house.
He was bitten on the leg by a dog, and the bone was shattered.
The neighbor wanted to kill the dog to take its liver and apply it to the wound.
Yue said:
Heaven has created this creature to guard and bark for people.
If I had not gone to your house, the dog would never have bitten me.
This is my fault, not the dog's.
Even if I could be cured by killing it, it would still be wrong.
How much more so if it does not benefit me and I would only incur a great sin?
Moreover, animals are ignorant, how can they be held accountable?
Because of this, the neighbor was moved by his words and did not kill the dog after all.
At the age of ten, he studied the Book of Han.
At thirteen, he studied the Brahmi script.
He mastered both of them.
He was also proficient in the pronunciation of the six states.
In the beginning, during the reigns of Emperors Huan and Ling, Zhi Chen translated the Dharma canon.
There was Zhi Liang, whose courtesy name was Ji Ming.
Zixuan's courtesy name was Shichang.
He also studied under Liang.
He extensively read scriptures and treatises, and thoroughly mastered them.
He practiced many worldly arts.
He was thin and dark, with small eyes and yellow pupils.
At that time, people said of him:
Zixuan, Zixuan, with yellow eyes,
Although his body is small, he is a wise counselor.
He originally upheld the great Dharma and refined the meaning of the scriptures.
At the end of the reign of Emperor Xian, the Han Dynasty was in great turmoil.
He fled to Wu with several dozen people from his hometown.
On the day of their departure, he only had one robe.
There was a guest who followed him.
It was bitterly cold and the guest had no robe. They called out to each other to sleep together.
In the middle of the night, the guest snatched his robe and left.
The next morning, his companions asked about the whereabouts of the robe.
Zixuan said:
Last night, the robe was snatched by a guest.
His companions all said, Why didn't you report it?
He replied:
If I had reported it, you would have certainly accused me of the crime of robbery.
How can it be right to kill a person with a single robe?
Those who heard about it near and far all marveled.
Later, the ruler of Wu, Sun Quan, heard that he was erudite and had talent and wisdom, so he summoned him.
He then asked about the profound meanings in the sutras.
Yue responded to the questions and resolved the difficulties without any doubts.
Quan greatly rejoiced and appointed him as a doctor.
He was made to guide the crown prince.
He was given much honor and rank.

although practiced, many of the sutras were in Sanskrit and no one could understand them.

He skillfully grasped the holy meaning and the words were elegant.
He also based himself on the Sutra of the Original Rise of Immeasurable Life,

He annotated the Sutra of Understanding the Origin of Life and Death.
